prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SPT0243-49 Band 4-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: First of three tunings in Band 4

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This science goal serves as the technical justification for all Band 4 science goals in both sources.
Spectral and Correlator Configurations: The three requested tunings in Band 4 are carefully chosen to maximize coverage of interesting spectral lines while minimizing overlap (see Fig. 3; the same lines are observed in both sources). The line widths of these two sources are quite broad, ~500km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines. While the lines observed at these frequencies are expected to be much narrower due to the more stringent gas conditions to excite the relevant energy levels, we nevertheless require a "buffer" of >~1000km/s (>2 FWHMs) from the rest frequencies of each line to the end of our spectral coverage to ensure the recovery of all the line flux. Additionally, since we aim to probe high velocity molecular outflows with these observations, we adjust the tunings to maximize coverage of the outflow tracers blueward of their rest frequencies, covering >~1500km/s blueward of the CO and OH+ lines; more extensive velocity coverage is provided by our Band 3 tunings. While spectral confusion is not expected to be relevant at the requested depth of our observations, the precisely-known redshifts of our sources still allow spectral decomposition in the event this issue arises. We configure the correlator in FDM mode with the full 3.75GHz bandwidth per sideband. Since we do not require the finest ~1km/s spectral resolution of this mode, we allow for spectral averaging of 16 channels (still twice the spectral resolution of the coarser TDM mode), for a velocity resolution of ~16km/s.
Sensitivity Requirements Our sensitivity requirements in Band 4 are dictated by Herschel observations of a variety of local starbursts, eg., Arp 220, the closest ULIRG (Rangwala et al. 2011) and NGC 1068, a Seyfert 2 host galaxy (Spinoglio et al. 2010). Using these spectra as templates, we can scale the fluxes of observed local galaxies in both redshift and 1.4mm flux to derive the expected flux of our objects. This method recovers the correct flux in the CO(5-4) and CO(6-5) lines that were observed in Cycle 0 to no worse than 30%, suggesting that the line strengths for these higher-frequency transitions are realisitic. Since we aim to resolve the emission in SPT0346-52, we divide up the integrated flux using the lens model presented in Hezaveh et al. (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. In SPT0243-49, only spatially unresolved measurements are feasible, so the requested sensitivity assumes no dilution of the source flux over multiple beams. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved (as in the case of SPT0346-52) with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations.
Imaging Requirements We request unresolved (>1") observations of SPT0243-49 and a resolution of ~1" for SPT0346-52. For SPT0346-52, this resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lensed images of the source (Fig. 2); indeed, the precisely constrained geometry of gravitational lensing and our custom visibility-based len modeling tool can accurately recover the correct source-plane configuration even if the observations are taken at low elevation, with an elongated synthesized beam such that the southern two images are not well-separated (Hezaveh et al. 2013, Appendix A).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SPT0346-52 Band 3-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: First of three tunings in Band 3

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This science goal serves as the technical justification for all Band 3 science goals in both sources.
Spectral and Correlator Configurations The spectral setup for Band 3 covers the largest possible number of interesting lines with no tuning overlap (Fig. 3; the same lines are observed in both sources). The line widths of these two sources are quite broad, ~500km/s, as measured in low- to mid-J CO lines. While the lines observed at these frequencies are expected to be much narrower due to the more stringent gas conditions to excite the relevant energy levels, we nevertheless require a "buffer" of >~1000km/s (>2 FWHMs) from the rest frequencies of each line to the end of our spectral coverage to ensure the recovery of all the line flux. This tuning scheme additionally covers many thousands of km/s blueward of the CO(6-5) line, allowing the detection of any high-velocity outflowing material. While spectral confusion is not expected to be relevant at the requested depth of our observations, the precisely-known redshifts of our sources still allow spectral decomposition in the event this issue arises. We configure the correlator in FDM mode with the full 3.75GHz bandwidth per sideband. Since we do not require the finest ~1.5km/s spectral resolution of this mode, we allow for spectral averaging of 8 channels, for a velocity resolution of ~12km/s.
Sensitivity Requirements Our sensitivity requirements in Band 3 are set to detect the multitude of faint spectral features shown in Fig. 3. The line strengths for many of these transitions can be estimated from stacking ALMA Cycle 0 Band 3 spectra of 22 DSFGs (Fig. 1; Spilker et al., submitted Oct. 2013). While constraints from the stack at these frequencies are largely driven by the two sources proposed here, the gas properties derived by Spilker et al. can be used to extrapolate the line fluxes to these higher energy levels. Note that these lines are indeed expected to be excited, even at these J-levels - Rangwala et al. (2011) find HCN in absorption up to extremely high transitions (J=17-16) in Arp 220. The proposed observations are an order of magnitude deeper than the observations used to derive the redshifts of these sources in Cycle 0, reaching 3sigma limits of ~0.14Jy km/s in both sources, sufficient to detect the lines marked in Fig. 3 at moderate significance. Since we aim to resolve the emission in SPT0346-52, we divide up the integrated flux using the lens model presented in Hezaveh et al. (2013; Fig. 2) and set sensitivity limits in order to significantly detect CO and H2O line emission in each lensed image. In SPT0243-49, only spatially unresolved measurements are feasible, so the requested sensitivity assumes no dilution of the source flux over multiple beams. For both sources, the lensing geometry precisely constrains the image-plane location of line flux, allowing faint spectral features to be recovered even if the source is resolved (as in the case of SPT0346-52) with no uv-tapering required. Simulated observations confirm that integrated measurements of faint lines can be recovered in this manner, making full use of the depth of these observations.
Imaging Requirements We request unresolved (>1") observations of SPT0243-49 and a resolution of ~1" for SPT0346-52. For SPT0346-52, this resolution is sufficient to resolve the separate lensed images of the source (Fig. 2); indeed, the precisely constrained geometry of gravitational lensing and our custom visibility-based len modeling tool can accurately recover the correct source-plane configuration even if the observations are taken at low elevation, with an elongated synthesized beam such that the southern two images are not well-separated (Hezaveh et al. 2013, Appendix A).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SPT0243-49 Band 3-3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Third of three tunings in Band 3

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: See the technical justification of Science Goal SPT0346-52 Band 3-1.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a full molecular line inventory in Bands 3 and 4 of the two highest known redshift dusty starburst galaxies accessible by ALMA, at z=5.7, close to the end of Cosmic reionization. A carefully-constructed tuning setup targets more than 40 lines of 13 molecular species expected to be detectable in these objects, tracing the full range of excitation conditions, heating mechanisms, outflow and dynamical signatures, and chemical enrichment pathways. At these rest frequencies, our observations will match and even exceed the sensitivity of local starbursts observed by Herschel/SPIRE. By exploiting high-resolution ALMA 870um continuum observations, low- and mid-J CO observations with ATCA and ALMA, [CII] emission from APEX, and full optical-to-radio SED coverage, these observations will stand as the definitive view of the ISM conditions in these objects, serving as an effective comparative study to local starbursts (e.g. Arp220) and intermediate-redshift analog systems (e.g. the Eyelash). In one target, we aim to spatially resolve the molecular line emission, allowing a 1 kpc-scale study of the near-Eddington-limited star formation underway in this object.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
